<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 118, 379, 143]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 193, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 246, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 487, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 338, 228, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 354, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 565, 806, 613]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 237, 485, 256]]<|/det|>
The speed–time graph represents a journey.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[268, 265, 725, 452]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 467, 920, 502]]<|/det|>
How does the graph show that the distance travelled in section X of the journey is greater than the distance travelled in section Y?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 510, 134, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 510, 806, 529]]<|/det|>
The area below section X of the graph is greater than the area below section Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 537, 134, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 537, 801, 555]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 564, 129, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 564, 922, 597]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 604, 133, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 604, 761, 621]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 892, 149]]<|/det|>

<label>13</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 443, 598, 581]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 607, 106, 625]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 607, 546, 625]]<|/det|> A beam of particles moves through a magnetic field. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 637, 641, 655]]<|/det|> In which situation do the particles experience a magnetic force? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 666, 133, 685]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 666, 675, 685]]<|/det|> a beam of \(\alpha\) -particles moving parallel to the magnetic field lines <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 693, 133, 711]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 693, 663, 711]]<|/det|> a beam of electrons moving parallel to the magnetic field lines <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 720, 133, 739]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 720, 777, 739]]<|/det|> a beam of \(\beta\) -particles moving perpendicularly across the magnetic field lines <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 747, 133, 765]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 747, 764, 765]]<|/det|> a beam of neutrons moving perpendicularly across the magnetic field lines <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 791, 106, 809]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 791, 579, 809]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct for the nucleus of any atom? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 820, 133, 838]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 820, 601, 838]]<|/det|> The nucleus contains electrons, neutrons and protons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 846, 133, 864]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 846, 675, 864]]<|/det|> The nucleus contains the same number of protons as neutrons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 873, 133, 892]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 873, 475, 892]]<|/det|> The nucleus has a total charge of zero. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 899, 133, 918]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 899, 660, 918]]<|/det|> The nucleus is very small compared with the size of the atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 438, 104, 456]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 438, 551, 457]]<|/det|> Which equation represents the \(\beta\)-decay of lead-209? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 470, 139, 490]]<|/det|> <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 467, 401, 497]]<|/det|> \[^{209}_{82}\mathbf{Pb} + \mathrm{\ ^{0}_{-1}e}\rightarrow^{209}_{83}\mathbf{Bi}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 504, 139, 528]]<|/det|> <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 504, 401, 534]]<|/det|> \[^{209}_{82}\mathbf{Pb} + \mathrm{\ ^{0}_{-1}e}\rightarrow^{209}_{81}\mathbf{Tl}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 541, 139, 565]]<|/det|> <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 541, 401, 570]]<|/det|> \[^{209}_{82}\mathbf{Pb}\rightarrow^{209}_{83}\mathbf{Bi} + \mathrm{\ ^{0}_{-1}e}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 577, 139, 600]]<|/det|> <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 577, 401, 606]]<|/det|> \[^{209}_{82}\mathbf{Pb}\rightarrow^{209}_{81}\mathbf{Tl} + \mathrm{\ ^{0}_{-1}e}\]
